activity.name: Kritter Kamp
activity.description: Kritter Kamp is a program for youth between the ages of 9 and 13 who have an interest in learning more about farm animals (dairy, goats, sheep, dog and rabbits). Experienced 4-H teens mentor the campers as they learn about animal behavior and care, different breeds, anatomy, the importance of agriculture and farm animals in our society, and general safety with animals. They will be provided with an animal and the equipment needed for the care and preparation of the animal for show. The highlight will be a show experience Saturday afternoon. Participants will demonstrate what they have learned as they present their animal in the show ring.

activity.name: Vaccinations
activity.description: Alpacas are vaccinated to protect them from disease. It's important to protect them from disease so they can produce wool and healthy crias (baby alpacas).
activity.types-of-vaccine: There are three types of vaccines: Killed or toxoid, modified live, and recombinant. With all of the vaccines, vaccinating a sick animal is not effective. Animals should be vaccinated 2-3 weeks after recovering. The vaccines also do not provide full protection, and efficacy of the vaccine is affected by many factors. Antibodies found in colostrum, the mother's first milk, can interfere with some vaccines, so crias often require additional boosters.
activity.killed-or-toxoid: Killed or toxoid vaccines contain the killed bacteria or virus, which means it is safe and the bacteria or virus is unable to reproduce. This makes the killed or toxoid vaccines preferred for pregnant animals. Killed vaccines do not always produce a strong immune response, so boosters are required 2-4 weeks after the first shot and once a year every year after.
activity.modified-live: Modified live vaccines have some parts of the bacteria or virus that trigger the immune response. This type of vaccine causes a mild infection, which increases the immune response and thus makes the vaccine last longer. Vaccines are designed for use in a specific species, so they shouldn't be used in alpacas or anything else in the camelid family.
activity.recombinant: Recombinant vaccines have a piece of the bacteria or virus, such as the spike protein causing the immune response. The bacteria or virus is unable to reproduce, while still causing a strong immune response, thus making the vaccine last longer.
activity.clostridial-vaccination: Alpacas and sheep need similar vaccines as sheep. Twice a year, in the spring and autumn, alpacas are given a clostridial vaccination. Crias can be vaccinated at 6-8 weeks and given a booster 4-6 weeks. Then, crias are given another booster at 6 months of age and every year after. If clostridial diseases have affected young animals on the farm, an extra vaccination can take place at 6-10 days of age for at-risk crias.

clostridial-diseases.c: Tetanus: Poisoning from a neurotoxin caused by Clostridium tetani. There are intermittent spasms of the muscles which can lead to death.

Pulpy kidney/enterotoxemia: Triggered when alpacas switch to feeds rich in starch, sugar, and/or protein. High levels of these nutrients cause normally present Clostridium perfringens Type D bacteria undergo rapid growth in the small intestine. As the bacteria increase in number, they release toxins causing damage to the small intestines, among other organs. Alpacas will abruptly go off feed, become lethargic, show signs of stomach pain, have loose stool, lose the ability to stand (due to the toxin's effects on the brain), and die quickly with no previous signs of disease.

Black leg: Causes swelling of the muscles and necrotizing myositis in large muscles. It's called black leg due to the color the muscles turn when animals are infected with the disease. The muscles have a sweetish odor, small bubbles, dry and spongy, with little edema. The tongue and diaphragm can also be affected. Black leg can cause acute, severe lameness, marked depression, fever, focal hot and painful swelling, cold and insensitive skin, with decreased blood flow to affected areas. Highly fatal.

Black's disease/infectious necrotic hepatitis: Caused by Clostridium novyi type B. Death is sudden with little to no clinical signs, but is limited to alpacas also infected with liver flukes. Lesions are grayish yellow, necrotic foci in diseased tissue. The lesions are caused by young, migrating flukes, the host to the bacteria.

Malignant edema: Caused by severe, often fatal spread of bacterial toxins through the bloodstream. Symptoms include loss of appetite, intoxication, and high fever, swelling around the site of infection.

activity.name: Rabbit Hopping
activity.summary: Rabbit hopping was first introduced in the 1970s in Europe. The rules are based on the rules of horse show jumping, modified to better suit rabbits. There are several different types of courses to compete in. The youth at 4-H assembled this video to demonstrate a straight course.

activity.name: Stomach
activity.details: Dairy cattle are ruminants, meaning their stomach is divided into four compartments. These compartments are often refered to as "stomachs". The food travels through the stomachs in reverse alphabetical order, the rumen first, then the reticulum, followed by the omasum, and finally the abomasum.

stomachs.rumen: The rumen is the first stomach. It is sometimes called the "fermentation vat", since it is the largest stomach in a cow's body (taking up 80%). Microorgamisms in the rumen, bacteria, fungi, and protazoa, ferment grasses, breaking down the carbohydrates. It also breaks down some protein. The protein that gets broken down in the rumen is called rumen degradeable protien; the protein that passes through unchanged is called rumen undegradeable protein, or by-pass protein. Volatile fatty acids are also produced in this stomach. Acetic acid is used for energy and milkfat. Butyric acid is an undesireable component of silage. Propionic acid is the precursor to glucose. The rumen is not fully developed in a newborn calf. It is important to give calves grain and hay to facilitate the development of the rumen. Normally, a calf starts chewing its cud at 2-3 weeks of age, when the rumen is more fully developed.
stomachs.reticulum: The reticulum is also known as the honeycomb. It is the stomach compartment nearest the heart. Hardware disease occurs in this stomach. Hardware disease happens when a cow swallows hardware. To decrease the risk of the hardware piercing the wall of the reticulum and piercing the heart, cows are given magnets using a balling gun. If the cow licks her nose after the magnet is given, it's likely that they have swallowed the magnet.
stomachs.omasum: The omasum is the third stomach, sometimes called the manyplies, since its many folds look like the pages of a book. The extra surface area provided by the folds helps the omasum to dehydrate food before it is passed on into the abomasum.
stomachs.abomasum: The abomasum is the fourth and final stomach. Since it is the stomach closest to a human's stomach, it is also known as the true stomach. It is the largest stomach at birth, taking up 25% of a calf's body. The esophogeal groove diverts milk past the rumen, which is not fully developed yet, and into the abomasum. The abomasum uses acid to break down proteins into amino acids, which will later be absorbed in the small intestine.

html.h4: Click on the question below to reveal some choices. Select whichever one you think is correct to test your knowledge!
html.button: Which stomach compartment is responsible for fermentation?

activity.name: Mimicry and Look-a-likes
activity.details: Evolutionary Mimicry is a term for when one species evolves to mimic another. The Bee Orchid evolved to mimic a female Orchid Bee. It not only looks like a female Orchid Bee, it also releases pheromones, a sort of smelly substance, to attract the male Orchid Bees.
activity.question: How does this help the Bee Orchid?
activity.answer: For the Bee Orchid, it increases the survival rate because it is able to spread more of its pollen.

activity.name: Hidden Colors
activity.details: Chromatography is the process of seperating out molecules based on their polarities.
activity.question: Could this still be done in space?
activity.answer: Since the capillary action that drives the molecules is not gravity dependant, Chromatography done in space would look similar to Chromatography done on Earth.

activity.name: Food Donation Project
activity.summary: The Botany Besties 4-H Club is committed to helping provide food security as our community service project. Our food donation project was crafted by one of our club members, Greta Garrison. Her goal is to provide fresh food access through the Friendship Donation Network which provides fresh vegetables to underserved members of our community. Last summer each club member was encouraged to plant a row in their garden for donation. When planning your gardens this spring, we invite you to dedicate a small space, and place in your heart to this program. For more information on how you can help, contact our project manager at stickandstonefarm@gmail.com, or visit:
activity.r: Friendship Donation Network Food Hubs: https://friendshipdonations.org/hubs/
Tompkins County Healthy Food For All: http://ccetompkins.org/food/healthy-food-for-all

activity.name: Crafting
activity.description: Pick up a craft kit at one of the library pickup locations (Dryden Southworth Library or Tompkins County Public Library at Green Street) and make the craft following the YouTube videos on this page. With the kits, we hope for kids to have a safe way to experience some of the activities held at the 4-H Fair while helping to develop a love for reading. These crafting sessions were created by kids for kids. We hope you enjoy!

textarea.name: entry.143964855
textarea.placeholder: Suggestions on how to improve the kits

activity.name: Helping improve Food Security
activity.summary: According to the US Census, 16.9% of individuals in Tompkins County live at or below the poverty line and 30% of children qualify for school lunch programs. In addition to the inability to pay for food, many individuals live in a food desert. This means that the closest grocery store may be miles away, too far to walk, and public transportation is inconvenient or unaffordable to this population. Vegetables do not keep well, and they need to be shopped for frequently in order to be fresh and have high nutritional value. For the individuals who are at or below the poverty line, there are limited food choices. Many are high in calories, but they are not always high in nutrition. Obtaining high nutrition vegetables can be very expensive and inaccessible for this group. I would like to create a comprehensive growing and education plan to address these issues. Overall, I would like to build bridges between the many organizations helping to combat food insecurity in my community to create a stronger program with a continuum of education and support from the beginning to the end of the program. Through word of mouth, support for each other, education, and collaboration, I hope for this program to become self-supporting, grow, and encourage others to help their communities. This pilot program will serve as a model to extend to other communities.

iframe.style: position: absolute; left: 0; top: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: 0;

activity.name: Cards to Thank Frontline Workers
activity.description: The Botany Besties 4-H club made cards to thank frontline workers. They told about people they knew who were frontline workers while making their cards.

you-will-need.y: A pair of fabric scissors or sharp all-purpose scissors.
A sewing machine makes the process faster, however you may use the needles and thread included in the kit.
An iron is helpful for making the material lay flat but is not essential.

instructions.i: Start a stopwatch to keep track of your hours spent working on the project. Lay all of the materials out on a spacious surface.

Navigate to the first YouTube video below or search the below tutorial: Make Fabric Face Mask at home | DIY Face Mask No Sewing Machine | Easy Face Mask Pattern by the channel Crafty Daily. URL: https://tinyurl.com/1wwas5jq

Watch and follow along with the video tutorial. Special notes: use the provided template instead of the dinner plate recommended in the video. Also, if you have a sewing machine use it in place of the needle and thread suggested in the video.

IMPORTANT! Stop the video at 2:42 and search this new video into YouTube.com or watch the second YouTube Video: It only takes 5 minutes to sew a simple mask | Face mask sewing tutorial | DIY face mask at home by the channel Mia. URL: http://tinyurl.com/v0nv2jrv Please start this new video at 3:30, and continue watching until 4:25. This video will show you how to attach the adjustable straps not shown in the previous video.

activity.name: Citizen Science Soil Project
activity.summary: We participated in a citizen science project run by the University of Oklahoma to take soil samples, which will be tested for new drugs. We participated to give back to the community that did so much for us.

iframe.style: position: absolute; left: 0; top: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: 0;

activity.name: Bird Count with Cornell
activity.summary: Plenty of people turned to birdwatching during the past year, seeking enjoyment and relaxation. Chickadees, cardinals, finches and other birds are doing their part to lift human spirits. The 24th annual Great Backyard Bird Count (GBBC), Feb. 12-15, is a great opportunity for budding birdwatchers and bird-count veterans to use their skills. People from around the world count the birds they see for at least 15 minutes on one or more days of the count, and then enter their checklists online. This helps to track the bird populations and migration routes.

activity.name: Stream Biomonitoring Sampling
activity.summary: The activity at the October 2020 4-H Finger Lakes Conservation Club meeting was working with staff from the CSI (Community Science Institute) to do stream biomonitoring sampling following protocols similar to the Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC). Members of the club learned about water quality and stream benthic macro invertebrates that live under the rocks in the stream. Water samples as well as organisms that were collected were taken and put into a data base to create a Biological Assessment profile to determine the biodiversity and health of the stream.
activity.results: Adrinna Hirtler from the CSI reported on the results of the stream biomonitoring: A few weeks ago some hardy volunteers and I finished sorting and identifying the 2020 benthic macroinvertebrate biomonitoring samples. I'm attaching a pdf showing the results for all 21 sites (in 12 different creeks) that were sampled. You can find more details about what the results mean on the CSI website (http://www.communityscience.org/bmi-results/) but to understand them at a quick glance, the number in the column on the right (Biological Assessment Profile or BAP) gives you an overall assessment of water quality at each site. The Cascadilla Creek downtown site curiously improved compared with recent years, though there are still quite a number of sites showing slight impacts. These results are now part of what's becoming a very nice long-term data set for many creeks in our area. Congratulations to all of the wonderful volunteers who have contributed over the years and who continue to contribute today. Thanks especially to Paul Allderige who came into the lab almost every week this winter for Thursday open lab nights to help work through all of the samples. We were limited by the number of people allowed in the lab at once due to the pandemic, but none of the volunteers who came to help (we sincerely appreciate you ALL) were limited in their energy, keen observations and enthusiasm. Thanks again for a fun and productive sample sorting season!

object.p: You don't have a PDF plugin, but you can download the file.

activity.name: Kindness Rocks
activity.description: Even during a pandemic, members of the Finger Lakes Conservation Club discovered "Kindness Rocks" and shared the idea with the Milk Duds/Jolly Ranchers 4-H club! Below is a selection of the rocks members recently painted. They will now leave these in the community for others to find. One Kindness Rock was left by a member of the Finger Lakes Conservation Club at one of the blue food pantry. The individual who found the rock posted a picture on Facebook saying how much they needed to hear the kind words that day. Help spread the kind words by making kindness rocks for your community as well! Two cloverbuds also made videos describing the kindness rocks (or peace rocks) they made with their club, the Milk Duds.

activity.name: Favorite Kitchen Tools
activity.description: What are your favorite kitchen tools? Submit your tool, a picture, and a short description of why you like it.
activity.pastry-cutter: My favorite tool is the pastry cutter because I love making pie crust and it helps me cut the butter in faster. Since it's metal, it stays cold and doesn't melt the butter, which makes the pie crust flakier.
activity.biscuit-cutter: My mom used this biscuit cutter when she was a kid. It wasn't used a whole lot, so we're trying to make up for that now. The scalloped edges turn brown and crispy, and every time I bite into a biscuit we cooked with this pastry cutter, I think of my mom and grammy.
activity.whisk: Whisks are super cool! If you whisk fast enough, you can make fluffed egg whites for marangues. You can use them when making homemade gravy to keep lumps from forming (this is mainly what I use the whisk for; my gravy is generally lumpy). They also combine your eggs and sugar into brownies. Yum! Thank you, whisk!

activity.name: How to Make Scones
activity.description: In the below video, the Sweets and Treats 4-H Club makes scones, raspberry, chocolate, and blueberry.

iframe.title: YouTube video player of making scones with Sweets and Treats
iframe.allow: accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture
iframe.style: position: absolute; left: 0; top: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: 0;

ingredients.ingredient: 1/2 cup of either: Rasberries, chocolate chips, or blueberries

directions.direction: In a bowl, whisk together flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt.
Cut the butter into tablespoon sized pieces, and using your hands, mix it into the flour until the flour and butter are indistinguishable.
Whisk the heavy cream and vanilla together.
Pour half of the heavy cream and vanilla mixture over the dough and sprinkle on half the sugar.
Add your choice of add ins and gently work them into the dough by folding it in half and then flattening five times.
Make a six inch round circle fo your dough about an inch thick and cut into wedges. Place the wedges on a lined baking sheet.
Pour on remaining heavy cream and vanilla mixture and sprinkle on remaining sugar.
Bake 14-16 minutes or until golden brown. Cool and enjoy!

activity.name: Kitchen Gallery
activity.description: Help us by sending in pictures of what you're cooking!

activity.name: Sausage Making
activity.description: The Milk Duds and Jolly Ranchers 4-H Club made sausages together as a club activity. Try these recipes at home!

polish-sausage.p: 25g fresh garlic (chopped in food processor or mini chopper)

italian-sausage.p: 5.7g fresh garlic (chopped in food processor or mini-chopper)
When mixing add 3 tbsp red wine vinegar per kg sausage

bratwurst.p: When mixing add 1 egg and 1/2 cup ice cold heavy cream per kg sausage

tips.tip: Keep your pork and liquids as cold as possible when mixing to prevent fat smearing.
After mixing, make and cook a small patty to test flavor before stuffing or packaging.
Make sure your scales are tared to zero before measuring.
Make sure the scales are measured in g or kg.
Add a quarter cup of water to the meat when grinding to achieve a finer grind.

activity.name: Table Setting
activity.description: A meal's no good if there's nowhere to put it...share pictures of your table setting as well!

activity.name: Veggie Art
activity.have-some-fun-with-your-veggies: We picked veggies from our garden and made art with them. You could make a person, a butterfly,or even a Mr. Potatohead! Afterwards, try to reuse the veggies. This could be making an omlet, a salad, a pizza, or just eating them plain! Don't worry, you don't need to cook the Mr. Potatohead. He's reusable veggie art! Have some fun with your veggie art, and eat healthy!

iframe.style: position: absolute; left: 0; top: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: 0;

activity.name: Garden of Healthy Eatin'
activity.description: This activity will take place at the 4-H Acres. It will be presented by the Plant and Environmental Sciences Team (often abbreviated as P.E.S.T) all day.

activity.name: Bakeoff
activity.summary: We know that there has been a lot of baking happening during the pandemic – it’s time to put on your apron, get out your favorite recipe and bake a delicious treat! The Holiday Bake off for Kids brings two important concepts together – positive youth development and baking! This contest is open to ALL youth 5 – 18 years of age. Youth work with an adult mentor to create an entry in one of the following categories: Cookies, Cakes, Breads, Decorated Items, Healthy Choices, and Candy. The goal of the contest is to increase knowledge and appreciation of food around holiday celebrations, to build and strengthen the tradition of families baking together, to recognize skill and culinary arts talent, and to have FUN! So what are you waiting for, spend some quality time with your sons and daughters and whip up something delicious in the kitchen, they will learn to cherish this time with you. The “Best in Contest” will earn the giant Golden Spoon Award. The Holiday Bake Off is held during National Baking Week in October at the Shops at Ithaca Mall.

activity.name: Iron Chef
activity.description: Teams of 3-4 kids make a meal in an hour using two secret ingredients. In the past, apple cobbler, apple and chipotle, and spaghetti have won the competition.

activity.name: Fair Projects
activity.description: Send us pictures of your fair projects this year.

activity.name: What do the ribbons mean?

object.p: You don't have a PDF plugin, but you can download the file.

activity.text-version: Projects are graded against a set of criteria, not against other projects. A blue ribbon means the project is excellent, and meets expectations. Red ribbons mean good, projects meet most expectations. White ribbons are given to projects that have met some expectations, but not all. At the 4-H Fair, some projects are also given a marking called "Selected for State", meaning that they exceeded expectations and the 4-Her went above and beyond in creating the project. The project will then go to be judged at the State Fair.

activity.name: Register Your Project
activity.details: Please visit the below pages for the forms and information on registering your project for the Tompkins County 4-H Fair.

activity.name: Sample evaluation
activity.description: Watch the following YouTube to see a sample fair project evaluation done between two 4-H members.

iframe.title: YouTube video player of a Sample 4-H Evaluation

activity.name: Awards
activity.description: Take a moment and reflect on how awesome everyone did this year!

activity.name: Fun at the Fair
activity.description: What's a fair without fun? Send in pictures of the fun you have at the fair, complete with a fun caption.

activity.name: Winning Wednesdays
activity.description: WINNING WEDNESDAYS at Texas Roadhouse! Take a break and take out or eat in at Ithaca Texas Roadhouse and they will donate 15% of your total check to the 4-H Youth Fair. When you support Texas Roadhouse, they support us! Just be sure you mention that you support 4-H to your server. Winning Wednesdays are July 7, 14 and 21.

activity.name: Fall Festival at Tractor Supply
activity.description: Visit 4-H at the Fall Festival at Tractor Supply! Have fun visiting animals, participating in a biggest pumpkin contest, and playing fun 4-H games!

activity.name: Donations to Tompkins County 4-H
activity.description: 4-H appreciates any donations. The donations will be used to support the grounds, membership and supply costs, and fund more fun activities for youth in the community. Please email Brenda Carpenter (btc6@cornell.edu) for more details on who to contact for you to make your donation.

activity.name: Chicken BBQ
activity.description: The Chicken BBQ is a fundraiser to support the grounds, membership and supply costs, and fund more fun activities for youth in the community.
